{
  "article_text": [
    "because of their interesting properties , the strongly correlated systems polarized a huge effort in last decades given in specially by developments in high critical temperature superconductivity ( degiorgi 1999 ) , heavy - fermion systems ( mathur et al . 1998 ) , metal - insulator transition and layered materials ( de boer et al . 1999 ) .",
    "the rigorous results obtained in this field are related mainly to one dimensional case being deduced by bethe anzats and exact result for @xmath0 are extremely rare .",
    "generated by these state of facts , in this paper an interesting procedure is presented that allows the construction of new exact ground states ( gs ) in arbitrary dimensions for strongly correlated systems starting from known domains of the phase diagram of a given model in the same dimension .",
    "the essence of the method is simple . given an examined hamiltonian ( @xmath1 ) together with its ground state @xmath2 valid in a restricted region of the phase diagram @xmath3 , based on an unitary transformation @xmath4 we obtain @xmath5 .",
    "the eigenvalues being unmodified by an unitary transformation , @xmath6 represents the gs wave function for @xmath7 . for a class of analysed hamiltonians",
    ", @xmath1 can be given however with a coupling constant set @xmath8 and an operatorial terms set @xmath9 as @xmath10 .",
    "taking @xmath11 in such a way to transform the components @xmath12 within the @xmath9 set ( i.e. @xmath13 , the unitary transformation change in fact @xmath8 to @xmath14 .",
    "based on this observation , from @xmath3 , the transformed @xmath15 region can be deduced , @xmath15 being the parameter space region where @xmath6 is valid .    in this paper",
    "we are using an explicitely given @xmath11 unitary transformation that transforms a spin density wave ( sdw ) into a charge density wave ( cdw ) wave function , a superconductor into a ferromagnet , a phase separation in spin into a phase separation in charge , and vice versa .",
    "the @xmath9 operatorial set",
    "is so fixed to preserve the analysed model in the class of extended hubbard models .",
    "the concretely analysed cases are connected to the model used by de boer at al .",
    "( 1995 a , b ) and montorsi and campbell ( 1996 ) describeing superconducting properties , and strack and vollhardt ( 1993 ) and aligia et al .",
    "( 1995 ) studying different density wave phases .",
    "our results underline the presence of new ferromagnetic , sdw and insulating gs wave functions in the phase diagram of the enumerated models .",
    "the remaining part of the paper is conscructed as follows : in capter ii .",
    "we describe the family of the model hamiltonians that we analyse and define our unitary transformation @xmath11 used during the paper .",
    "chapter iii .",
    "contains the study of different concrete hamiltonians and the results obtained . in capter iv .",
    "we present the summary , and appendices containing the mathematical details close the paper .",
    "for the starting point we are introducing below a class of model hamiltonians that are used in the remaining part of the paper for the exemplification of the used procedure .",
    "we are developing here our study in a class of extended hubbard models that generically can be given in the following form @xmath16 in this expression a general @xmath17 term represent the contribution of the @xmath18 operator in the extended hubbard hamiltonian @xmath1 , taken into account with the coupling constant @xmath19 .",
    "the terms taken into consideration , in order , are the following .",
    "the kinetic energy contribution has the form @xmath20 where @xmath21 are canonical fermi operators wich describe electrons on a d - dimensional lattice , @xmath22 denoting nearest - neighbor sites .",
    "the hubbard on - site interaction is taken as @xmath23 where @xmath11 represents the hubbard coupling and @xmath24 denotes the particle number operator for electrons with spin @xmath25 on site @xmath26 . the bond - charge interaction is taken as @xmath27 for a density - density type interaction we have taken into account the @xmath28 contribution that describes a nearest - neighbor coulomb interaction .",
    "heisenberg type spin - spin interactions follows written for spin densities .",
    "these interactions have been taken anisotropic and are represented by @xmath29 the spin operators in this expression are standard , namely @xmath30 .",
    "a pair hopping term follows given by the hamiltonian term @xmath31 after this step three - particle interactions are taken into consideration .",
    "a correlated hopping term testing the opposite spin occupancy along the bond of the hopping is represented by @xmath32 correlation effects produced by an empty site or a double occupancy are described by @xmath33 \\ : .\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] finally , a four - particle interaction takes into consideration a double occupancy - double occupancy type correlation effect along different bonds @xmath34 furthermore , in the starting hamiltonian given in eq.([eqh ] ) , @xmath35 represents the chemical potencial , and @xmath36 is the external magnetic field applied in @xmath37 direction .    concerning the notations from the hamiltonian @xmath38 we mention some limiting cases that emerges during the presentation .",
    "when the heisenberg type interaction eq.([heis ] ) becomes isotropic , the notation of the coupling constant becomes @xmath39 and the corresponding hamiltonian term is denoted by @xmath40 where we have @xmath41 .",
    "furthermore , in case of @xmath42 , the common notation of the @xmath43 interactions becomes @xmath44 where @xmath45 \\ : , \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath46 .    in the following paragraph",
    "we are presenting some basic wave functions that emerge during the paper .",
    "we are presenting in this section the ground state wave functions used during the paper .",
    "the superconductor state is considered in the form of an @xmath47-pairing state as follows @xmath48 is the bare vacuum with no fermions present , and @xmath49 creates the @xmath47-pairs within the sytem .",
    "here @xmath50 represents the number of lattice sites , and @xmath51 the number of @xmath47-pairs present .",
    "the ferromagnetic wave - function is taken as @xmath52 where @xmath53 and @xmath54 are arbitrary disjoint sets of lattice points , wich together built up the whole lattice .",
    "the number of components in @xmath53 and @xmath55 is considered different .",
    "the density wave functions considered are the following . the spin - density - wave ( sdw ) state is given by @xmath56 where @xmath57 and @xmath58 represent sublattices of a given lattice .",
    "we mention that during the paper , in case of density waves we are working on bipartite lattice with odd and even sublattices .",
    "the unitary transformation that we analysed during the paper has the form @xmath60 as presented in appendix 1 .",
    ", @xmath11 given in eq.([uni ] ) represents indeed an unitary transformation .",
    "it transforms the presented wave functions ( see appendix 2 . for details ) as follows @xmath61 based on eq.([uni ] ) the hamiltonian from eq.([eqh ] ) can be unitary transformed .",
    "this procedure may be started with the transformation of the creator and annihilator operators ( details presented in appendix 3 . ) .",
    "@xmath62 based on eq.([uni1 ] ) the transformation of the particle number operators can be given .",
    "as presented in appendix 4 . , the following results are obtained @xmath63 using eqs.([uni1],[uni2 ] ) the complete hamiltonian presented in eq.([eqh ] ) can be unitary transformed based on @xmath11 .",
    "for example in the case @xmath64 @xmath65 , and @xmath66 for all @xmath26 , we obtain the following final result ( see appendix 5 . ) @xmath67 in this relation the renormalized coupling constants obtained after the transformation are denoted with a tilde superscript their values being @xmath68",
    "based on the results presented in chapter ii .",
    "we are analysing different concrete cases as follows .",
    "de boer et al ( 1995 a ) in the study of the @xmath47-pairing ground state in the extended hubbard model used the following model hamiltonian @xmath69 obtaining a superconducting @xmath47-pairing ground state at @xmath70 @xmath71 in the following parameter space region @xmath72 where @xmath73 represents the number of electrons within the system .",
    "based on this result , taking into consideration that from eq.([x1 ] ) the unitary transformed @xmath47-pairing state represents a ferromagnetic state , using eqs.([res1],[res ] ) we obtain a ferromagnetic ground state in the same model in the parameter space region @xmath74 and @xmath75 \\ : .\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the ground state energy of this ferromagnetic state is given by @xmath76 the position of the obtained ferromagnetic ground state in the @xmath77 phase diagram of the model relative to the @xmath47-pairing state is illustrated in fig . 1 .",
    "the second hamiltonian that we analyse concretely here has been studied by montorsi and campbell ( 1996 ) .",
    "the authors being interested in the emergence possibilities of @xmath47-pairing superconductivity , used the hamiltonian @xmath78 this hamiltonian has been studied by montorsi and campbell ( 1996 ) obtaining @xmath47-pairing superconducting ground state for @xmath79 in the domain @xmath80 where @xmath81 , @xmath82 representing the number of nearest neighbours .    in appendix 6 .",
    "we convert the hubbard term from eq.([h2 ] ) into the form it has in ( [ u ] ) .",
    "the unitary transformation presented in chapter ii then gives a ferromagnetic ground state for @xmath83 in the region @xmath84 where @xmath85 , and @xmath86 .",

    "we are analysing now model hamiltonians giving density wave states .",
    "we start the presentation of our results with the hamiltonian used by strack and vollhardt ( 1993 ) @xmath87 the last term from @xmath88 can be easily transformed into the form used in eq.([u ] ) ( see appendix 7 . ) . for the model from eq.([xy5 ] ) a paramagnetic insulator has been deduced in the pase diagram domain @xmath89 and a charge density wave region has been obtained in the region ( strack and vollhardt , 1993 ) : @xmath90 by the unitary transformation presented above we obtain instead of the phase from eq.([xy1 ] ) an other paramagnetic insulator phase present in the region @xmath91 and a spin density wave phase instead of the domain eq.([xy2 ] ) in the region @xmath92 the results from eqs.([xy3 ] , [ xy4 ] ) are valid in a model similar to eq.([xy5 ] ) in which however the density - density type coupling has been replaced with @xmath93 and @xmath94 , see appendix 7 .",
    "the results connected to the hamiltonian @xmath95 are summarised in fig .",
    "3 .    the next hamiltonian that we analysed is connected to an extended hubbard model studied by de boer et al . ( 1995 b )",
    "@xmath96 based on this hamiltonian , de boer et al .",
    "( 1995 b. ) proved the existence of a sdw ground state in the following region of the parameter space @xmath97 using the presented unitary transformation , from eq.([xxx1 ] ) we obtain a cdw ground state in the following region of the phase diagram of the same model @xmath98 de boer and schadschneider ( 1995 b. ) obtained also a fully polarized ferromagnetic state in the following region @xmath99 interestingly , from the phase presented in eq.([xxx2 ] ) our unitary transformation gives an insulating ground state in the domain @xmath100 the obtained results related to the phase diagram of the hamiltonian @xmath101 are summarized in fig .",
    "another extended hubbard hamiltonian containing in it s ground state phase diagram density waves has been analysed by aligia et al .",
    "( 1995 ) @xmath102 \\ : .",
    "\\label{xxx3}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] they found a region of parameters in the phase diagram where a cdw phase is the ground state of the system in the domain @xmath103 where @xmath104 based on this result , using the presented unitary transformation ( see appendix 8 . ) we have obtained a sdw ground state in the domain @xmath105 where @xmath106 in eq.([xxx4 ] ) we have @xmath107 the position of the deduced cdw phase in the phase diagram of the model is presented in fig . 5 .",
    "in this paper , we have presented a procedure that based on an explicitely given unitary transformation allows the rigorous deduction of new phase diagram domains starting from known ground state solutions of a given model .",
    "the method is not model - dependent and can be applied for arbitrary dimensions .",
    "we have applied this method to find new stable spin - density wave , charge - density wave , ferromagnetic and a paramagnetic insulator domains of different extended hubbard type models .",
    "aligia , a. a. , arrachea , l. , gagliano , e. r. , 1995 , phys .",
    "b * 51 * , 13774 .",
    "+ de boer , j. , koerpin , v. e. , schadschneider , a. , 1995 a , phys .",
    "74 * , 789 .",
    "+ de boer , j. , schadschneider , a. , 1995 b , phys .",
    "lett . * 75 * , 4298 .",
    "+ de boer , p. k. , et al . , 1999 ,",
    "b. * 60 * , 10758 .",
    "+ degiorgi , l. , 1999 , rev .",
    "mod . phys . * 71 * , 687 .",
    "+ mathur , n. d. , et al .",
    ", 1998 , nature * 394 * , 39 .",
    "+ montorsi , a. , campbell , d. k. , 1996 , phys .",
    "b * 53 * , 5153 .",
    "+ strack , r. , vollhardt , d. , 1993 , phys .",
    "lett . * 70 * , 2637 .",
    "in this chapter dedicated to appendices we are presenting the mathematical details of the calculation .",
    "this appendix prove the unitary nature of the operator @xmath11 .",
    "we must deduce @xmath108 , where @xmath109 is the adjoint of @xmath11 .",
    "indeed , @xmath11 can be written as @xmath110 where @xmath111 . with this notation",
    "we have @xmath112 , where @xmath111 .",
    "then we find @xmath113 .",
    "since @xmath114 we obtain @xmath115 for all @xmath26 . as a consequence @xmath116 , so @xmath11 is indeed an unitary transformation .      in this appendix",
    "the effect of @xmath11 on the wave - functions is presented .",
    "let consider first the unitary transformation of the superconducting ( @xmath47-pairing ) wave - functions .",
    "if we consider a single doubly occupied state present in the wave function at site @xmath26 , the effect of the operator @xmath117 on this state is to transform it in a single occuped state with spin up as follows @xmath118 the effect of @xmath119 on the same state for @xmath120 becomes @xmath121 from these equations it can be seen that the effect of @xmath11 on empty sites is to introduce a sigle occupancy with spin down on these sites .",
    "however , in case of doubly occupied sites containing an @xmath47-pair , the effect of @xmath11 is to transform these states in single occupied states with spin up .",
    "based on these relations , for a general wave function containing @xmath51 @xmath122-pairs distributed on different sites we obtain @xmath123 apart from a phase factor , this is a ferromagnetic state , if @xmath124 , where @xmath50 represents the number of lattice sites .",
    "the study of density waves starts from the observation that @xmath117 transforms differentially the single occupied states with up and down spin .",
    "indeed , for an up spin single occupied state we have @xmath125 but for the spin down counterpart we obtain @xmath126 using this property , starting from a spin - density wave state , using @xmath11 we find @xmath127 the obtained state is a charge - density state .",
    "the transformation under @xmath117 of the creation and annihilation operators is presented in this appendix . starting with annihilation operators , we have for the spin up case @xmath128 from where @xmath129 arise . for different indices",
    "@xmath130 we find @xmath131 .",
    "similarly , for the opposite spin direction and different indices we obtain @xmath132 , and for @xmath133 one have @xmath134 @xmath135 in the case of creation operators , for up spin , independent on indices we have @xmath136 . for down spin , in case of different indices we obtain @xmath137 .",

  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> from known phase diagram regions of different model hamiltonians describing strongly correlated systems we deduced new domains of the ground state phase diagram of the same model by an unitary transformation . </S>",
    "<S> different types of extended hubbard hamiltonians were used for the starting point and the existence of new stable spin - density wave , charge - density wave , ferromagnetic state and a paramagnetic insulator is demonstrated . the used procedure itself </S>",
    "<S> is dimension independent .    </S>",
    "<S> # 1#2 </S>"
  ]
}
